ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TELEPHONE CHARGES AND
RENTALS
(Introduction of sliding scale)


    1. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Communications if he will ascertain from the Singapore Telephone Board whether the Board will consider (i) introducing a sliding scale of charges and rentals to apply to major subscribers, such as hotels; and (ii) reducing the charge in respect of coloured telephones, since it is understood that there is no difference in cost to the Board between black and coloured telephones.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Singapore Telephone Board

Column: 306

is currently revising the whole tariff structure of its facilities, no changes are being contemplated until such study has been completed and accepted by the Board.

    The review does cover the subjects mentioned by the Member for Jalan Kayu, namely, whether or not there should be a sliding scale of charges and rentals for major subscribers such as hotels, and the different rates charged for coloured telephones.

Column: 306

TELEX SERVICE FOR COMMERCE
AND INDUSTRY


    2. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Communications if the Telex Service that obtains in Singapore is adequate for the Republic's commercial and industrial needs.

Column: 307



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, due to the unfortunate limited capacity of the existing manual telex switchboards and the current shortage of teleprinters and associated equipment, it has not been possible to provide applicants for telex service with immediate connection. In fact, there is at present a waiting list of 42 potential telex subscribers and it is likely that this list may become larger. In addition, there are 21 subscribers now using limited service with machines, not equipped with tape- perforation facilities, who have requested that they be supplied with machines incorporating these facilities which we are, unfortunately, not able to meet because of the present shortage of teleprinters.

    It is anticipated, however, that the 42 potential subscribers will be given service by May of next year, that is, six months from now, when additional manual switchboards and teleprinter equipment, which have been ordered by the Telecommunications Department, are expected to be ready for service. It will also be possible then to provide some of the 21 subscribers with tape-perforation facilities.

    I may also add that provision has been made in the Departmental Development Estimates for next year for the purchase and installation of an Automatic Telex Exchange at an estimated cost of $600,000 and it is anticipated that the equipment will be ready for service in 1970. This equipment, together with teleprinters and associated equipment for which an additional sum of $1 million has been budgeted in next year's Development Estimates, will ensure that existing subscribers will be given a fully automatic telex service and ample capacity for the anticipated growth in the immediate future.

TOA PAYOH HOUSING ESTATE
(Post Office)


    3. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Communications when the Government will build a post office at

Column: 308

the Toa Payoh Housing Estate in view of the rapid increase in the number of residents in that area and the policy of the Government to encourage savings with the Post Office Savings Bank.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Postal Services Department plans to establish a delivery post office in the town centre of the Toa Payoh Housing Estate to provide the full range of postal facilities to the residents living in this estate. It is expected to operate the post office in rented premises for a change in a large building complex which is due to be constructed in the latter half of 1969.

WOODLANDS
(Post Office)


    4. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Communications when the Government will build a post office at Woodlands to serve the large number of residents in the area.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: The Postal Services Department has plans to build a post office at Woodlands in conjunction with the development of the proposed Woodlands New Town Scheme, which is understood to be still in the planning stage.

    At present, however, postal facilities in the Woodlands area are being provided by, firstly, a postal agency and, secondly, a mobile post office.

    The postal agent, Mr Lim Soon Teng of 1408 Woodlands Road, Singapore, 25, who terminated his services on 23rd September this year, has since agreed to resume operation of the postal agency with effect from the 2nd of this month.

    As a service improvement, arrangements were made from 28th October this year for the mobile post office to increase the frequency of calls from once a week on Wednesdays, to thrice a week on Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays.

PORT OF SINGAPORE
AUTHORITY
(Employment of convicted persons)


    5. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Communications if he is aware that applicants for employment with the Port of Singapore Authority who have any criminal convictions recorded against them are rejected outright by the Authority; and if he will ascertain from the Authority whether the Authority will give consideration to such applicants in future recruitments in cases where the offences committed by them are not of a nature which will in any way be prejudicial to the interests of the Authority and the persons concerned have satisfactorily served their sentences, as employment will assist in rehabilitating them in society.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson is no doubt aware that the Port of Singapore Authority employs a very large work force of approximately 9,000 persons, and since the smooth operation of our port activities is vital to the economic weIl.being of Singapore, it follows that the P.S.A, must make a careful assessment so that only persons of reasonably good character and integrity are recruited into its service.

    It is incorrect to say that all applicants with criminal convictions are being rejected outright by the P.S.A. As a matter of fact, since 1966, 62 persons with minor offences and 16 persons with criminal records have been recruited, after satj~fying the P.S.A, that they had indeed turned over a new leaf.

Column: 309

SECOND-HAND AND OBSOLETE
BUSES ON ROAD


    6. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Communications whether he is aware that a certain bus company is using second-hand and obsolete buses purchased from another bus company, and whether such buses are roadworthy.

Column: 310



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, it has been the policy of our Registrar of Vehicles Department for some years not to permit second-hand and obsolete buses to be registered for use as public service vehicles. Unfortunately, it is on record that seven old buses which were purchased by a certain bus company from another bus company were approved for registration for use as public service vehicles early in 1966. But when this was discovered after an investigation, the senior official responsible for approving these cases was retired from service in the public interest in August 1966. The buses concerned are still in use, subject to half-yearly mechanical inspections as to their roadworthiness.

Column: 310

TICKET BINS IN BUSES


    7. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister f or Communications whether he is aware that bins for used tickets are not provided in some buses, and what steps he proposes to take in the matter.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: In October 1968, all bus companies were asked and have agreed to install bins for used tickets in their buses. Many of the buses already have such bins. There may be a few bus companies who have not installed them, in which case by March 1969, that is four months from now, when they do come for the half-year inspection and they still fail to provide litter bins, their buses will not be re- licensed.

SCOOTERISTS, MOTOR-CYCLISTS
AND PILLION-RIDERS
(Legislation for compulsory use of crash helmets)


    8. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider introducing legislation to make it compulsory for scooterists, motorcyclists and pillion-riders to wear crash helmets.

Column: 311



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: It is somewhat early to contemplate legislation for the compulsory wearing of crash helmets for scooterists, motor-cyclists and pil lion-riders, because whether there is, in fact, an adequate supply of approved types of crash helmets and, what is important, at reasonable prices available in Singapore has yet to be determined. In the meantime, we will continue to encourage riders to wear crash helmets voluntarily to protect themselves against fatal accidents.

    The Member for Katong will recall that in August this year I appointed a Transport Advisory Board with very wide terms of reference to study ways and means on how to improve the public transport service of Singapore. One of the members of the Transport Advisory Board is representing the National Safety First Council of Singapore, which body has been strongly advocating the compulsory use of crash helmets. He has been advised to raise this subject for consideration by the Transport Advisory Board. When this 'Board is in a position to submit their recommendations on the subject, I will be in a better position to reply to the question now posed by the hon Member.

ROAD COURTESY AND
OBSERVANCE OF TRAFFIC
REGULATIONS BY ROAD USERS


    9. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Communications, in view of the frequent disregard for traffic regulations and road courtesy by 'motorists and pedestrians, if he proposes to take appropriate steps to encourage social responsibility and dis cipline where the use of roads is concerned.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I agree with the Member for Katong that there is, unfortunately, today far too frequent a disregard for traffic regulations and road courtesy not only by motorists and pedestrians but also by most other road users in Singapore.

    This is reflected by the large number of traffic offences committed by motorists

Column: 312

alone, which have come to the notice of our Traffic Police and Divisional Police, namely, a total of 146,297 cases for the six-month period from 1st April to 30th September this year.

    Although our Registry of Vehicles and Traffic Police have been actively associated with the work of the Road Traffic Safety Committee of the National Safety First Council in the promotion of various safety-first campaigns this year and of others planned for next year, I can assure the Member for Katong that my Ministry will be mounting a sustained campaign on road safety and compliance with traffic regulations for 1969.

SINGAPORE PAYA LEBAR
INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT
(Development)


    10. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Communications what preparatory, renovating or developmental work is being undertaken at the Singa pore Paya Lebar International Airport to prepare it as a major international civil aviation centre in this part of the world.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: May I begin my reply to the Member for Serangoon Gardens by stating that although Paya Lebar International Airport is already a major international civil aviation centre in this part of the world, yet every effort is being made to maintain and develop our airport to keep pace with the fast changing modern developments in aviation today.

    The following projects have already been completed:

    (i) The air-conditioning of the arrivals block in our Passenger Terminal Building;

    (ii) The redevelopment of an existing hangar to accommodate Boeing 707 aircraft of Malaysia-Singapore Airlines, of which there are three in number at present.

Column: 313



    (iii) The construction of eight additional new airline offices;

    (iv) The construction of a new car park to accommodate an additional 200 cars, making a total of 380 parking stands, not for free but for a charge;

    (v) The installation of an Airfield Location Beacon.

The following projects are now in progress:

    (i) The extension of the existing runway from the present 9,000 feet to 11,000 feet to cater for the larger types of aircraft that will be put into service through Singapore in the near future. In addition, there is re-surfacing of the entire length of the runway to strengthen it for heavier aircraft like the Boeing 747 (better known as the Jumbo jet). This project is scheduled for completion by the middle of next year.

    (ii) Installation of a Radar Training Simulator in the Departmental Training School which will be completed before the end of the current year;

    (iii) An instrument landing system has been contracted for and is scheduled for operation by August 1969;

    (iv) An existing hangar is being modified for the use of the Boeing 737 of Malaysia/ Singapore Airlines. There will be five coming by next year. And the hangar is scheduled for completion by the end of January 1969, i.e., two months from now;

    (v) A new High Capacity Foam Tender has been ordered and is due for delivery in 1969;

    (vi) Land has been acquired and a site prepared for the installation of approach lighting for the extended runway.

Column: 314



    Finally, a firm of consultants have also been appointed from the United Kingdom under the Colombo Plan, namely, Messrs. Scott Wilson Kirkpatrick & Partners, to conduct a survey and prepare a detailed Master Plan for the development of our International Airport, in phases up to 1990.

OIL POLLUTION OF SEA-WATERS AROUND SINGAPORE


    11. Mr Lim Soo Peng asked the Minister for Communications whether investigations indicate that oil pollution of the sea-waters around Singapore is to a great extent caused by oil tankers and other ships; and, with the increase in the number of such vessels calling at Singapore, what steps have been or will be taken to minimise such oil pollution and make more beaches, free of oil pollution, available to the public.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, investigations, unfortunately, do indicate that the increasing oil pollution of the sea-waters around Singapore is related to the increase in the number of ships calling here, in view of the almost universal use of oil as fuel for ships. For the month of November 1968, the average daily number of ships anchored in the Port of Singapore was over 200.

    Oil pollution arises in the following ways:

    (1) From accumulated accidental spillage, particularly during bunker operations, which can reach large proportions, and it is difficult to control such offences, as offenders must be caught in the act.

    (2) Oil which has been discharged by ships outside our territorial waters and is then carried into Singapore shores, by the action of the wind and tide.

    (3) Damaged ships, leaking oil, which come to Singapore for repairs.

Column: 315



    (4) Oil refineries (we have quite a number of them around), and

    (5) Ship repair yards. They make the money, hut also pollute our shores.

    Officers of the Port of Singapore Authority do carry out sea patrols, in the course of which a watch is being kept for cases of oil pollution. Helicopter pilots of the Royal Air Force also co-operate by reporting any incident they observe.

    Prior to September 1968, only warnings were given to the offenders. Since then however, seven summonses have been issued against offenders, two of which have resulted in court fines of $75 each, while the other five cases are still pending.

    Finally, the Port of Singapore Authority is also constructing a special vessel to skim floating oil from the surface of the sea.

ADMINISTRATION OF MUSLIM
LAW (FITRAH) RULES, 1968
(Action against instigators of opposition to)


    12. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap asked the Minister for Social Affairs whether he is aware that there are persons who are instigating members of the Muslim community to oppose the Administration of Muslim Law (Fitrah) Rules, 1968, and what action he has taken or proposes to take in the matter.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Inche Buang Bin Omar Junid) (for the Minister for Social Affairs)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir,I have been asked by the Minister to reply. No complaints have been received by the Ministry of Social Affairs that there are persons instigating mem bers of the Muslim community to oppose the Administration of Muslim Law (Fitrah) Rules, 1968. Should there be such persons, there is provision under Rule 13 (3) of the Fitrah Rules to deal with them. Rule 13 (3) states as follows:

    'Any person who obstructs, prevents or restrains or does any act likely to obstruct,

Column: 316

prevent or restrain any person from paying fitrah under these Rules and any person who without lawful authority receives any fitrah from any person, shall be guilty of an offence under these Rules and shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months or to both such fine and imprisonment.'

CRECHES
(Extension of services)


    The following Question stood in the name of Madam Chan Choy Siong ---

    13. To ask the Minister for Social Affairs whether he will consider extending the services of creches till late evening to enable working women to have more time for participation in community activities.

    Mr Speaker: Madam Chan Choy Siong.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: Question No. 13.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng) (for the Minister for Social Affairs): The creche service has been set up primarily to meet the needs of working women in providing a proper place for the care of their infant children (under six years old) when they are at work. As such, the 10 creches operated by the Social Welfare Department are open from 7 am, to 5 p.m, on weekdays and from 7 am, to 1 p.m, on Saturdays.

    Although extending the services of the creches to late evening would help some working women to have more time for participation in community activities, this will definitely not be in the interests of the children themselves. It is a well-known fact that for the proper growth and development of infants, it is essential that they spend as much time as possible with their parents, brothers and sisters from whom they will receive and can express their love and affection. Since under the existing arrangement children attending creches will be away from their homes for as much as 10 hours a day on weekdays and six hours a day on Saturdays, any

Column: 317

extension of these hours to late evening will be undesirable, as it would mean that the children would be spending all their waking hours at the creches, leaving little or no time with their parents and other members of the family.

    For the above reasons, the Ministry considers it inadvisable to extend the services of creches beyond the hours as provided at present.

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE
(Particulars)


    14. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Social Affairs, during the period 1st January, 1968 to 31st October, 1968, (a) how many persons have been given public assistance and the total amount paid out; and (b) how many persons have had such assistance terminated and the reasons therefor.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng (for the Minister for Social Affairs): From 1st January to 31st October, 1968, a total sum of $4,837,454.80 was paid out under the public assistance scheme to an average of 16,775 families a month. It has been estimated that an average family on public assistance consists of five persons. Working on this basis, a total of 838,760 persons, on the average of 83,876 persons per month, has been given public assistance during this period.

    From 1st January to 31st October, 1968, a total of 3,104 families have had their public assistance terminated. Taking an average of five persons to a family, approximately 15,520 persons, or an average of 1,552 persons per month, have had their public assistance terminated. The main reasons for the termination of public assistance to the 3,104 families for the period 1st January to 31st October, 1968 are as follows:

    Head of a family having found employment; wife having found employment; children having found employment; family having secured a school tuck-shop: members of the family commenced hawking; receipt of a lump sum

Column: 318

payment by way of workmen's compensation, Central Provident Fund benefits; receipt of maintenance by an estranged wife; re-marriage of divorcees or widows; receipt of financial assistance from relatives; family having migrated from Singapore; death of a person who is the sole recipient of public assistance; admission of single persons to welfare homes: withdrawal on own accord. Other miscellaneous cases were those of families requiring temporary assistance only.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, in regard to those cases where public assistance was terminated, were there a number of cases where public assistance was terminated because the eldest child of the family was recruited for national service?

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: Yes, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Rodrigo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have reason to believe that in such cases it might only tend to aggravate the financial situation of the family. Can the Parliamentary Secretary assure the House that in such cases the utmost consideration would be given with a view to preventing further hardship to the family?

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the cases of those who were recruited for national service and whose public assistance had been terminated, we have got a means test. We always consider whether or not the family would be in a state of hardship before we terminate the public assistance.

    The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Inche A. Rahim Ishak): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the House rose for the adjournment last Friday night, I was on the point of answering questions which were raised by the Members for Delta, Crawford and Ulu Pandan concerning our international relations and our foreign affairs policy. The Member for Delta asked what the present state was of ASEAN, what future it would have and whether any concrete progress could be achieved by it. Well, Sir, even as I commenced replying to her, things were taking place in Bangkok where our Minister for Foreign Affairs along with other Ministers of the ASEAN member states had been conferring, among other things, to keep ASEAN

Column: 320

viable, and an on-going concern despite the little dispute that was going on between two member states. It is on record, I am heartened to say, that some understanding has been reached between the Foreign Minister of the Philippines and the Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia at Bangkok, subject to the concurrence of their respective governments, which will, we hope, allow ASEAN a fresh opportunity to carry on business. You cannot allow a business enterprise to close shop after having started business just because differences occur between two of its board members, as differences are only to be expected from time to time over one another's specific problem. Even the European Economic Community, which is not just 10 years old but almost 20 years old, does not function with unanimity on all issues. One example is the admission of the United Kingdom into the common market.

    ASEAN has as yet not brought direct benefit 10 its members, but this should occasion no special disappointment because it s only just over a year old. During the year substantial progress has been made to clarify and define approaches to greater economic co- operation among member states. At the recent Ministerial Meeting held in Djakarta last August, areas of co-operation have been defined in food production and supply (including fisheries), shipping, transportation, telecommunications, civil aviation and tourism. In fact, on tourism, some of the recommendations have already been implemented, for example, the introduction of a seven-day free visa in Singapore and facilities for package and chartered tours. There is also the bilateral agreement with Indonesia on the Bali tourist potential.

    In keeping with our policy of making the maximum number of friends, Singapore must co-operate with as many countries as possible for mutual benefit, particularly so in the case of our immediate neighbours, namely, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines. This is a natural grouping of nations in a common neighbourhood, but effort

Column: 321

must be made to foster the community spirit so that mutual understanding and co-operation is further developed. Whatever the difficulties of the moment, the ASEAN concept must be maintained - even as a state of mind. Last Friday night, I said that we have no illusions about regionalism or about joining ASEAN. For in the ultimate, the small nations in a single neighbourhood have to stick together regardless of whether it is in Asia, Africa, Europe or South America.

    The Members for Delta, Crawford and Ulu Pandan also touched on our defence build-up and would like to know how it would affect our non-aligned policy and our commitment to regional co-operation, against a back ground of turbulence in the Southeast Asian region. And as the Member for Crawford puts it, the possibility of shifting balance of power within the region arising from the possibility of an early end to the Vietnam war and the emergence of a well-tried, well-organised military organisation in Vietnam larger than that of our members of the region.

    In the first place. Sir, I do not see any incompatibility between our defence build-up, which will cost us some $350 million in next year's budget, and our non-aligned policy. There is neither in consistency nor incompatibility, it is an inevitable concomitant of our independence that we develop and exercise our muscles for defence purposes, and, as far as we are concerned, for defence purposes only. It is like members of the fair sex deciding these days to take up karate or judo. I am sure these precautionary measures are for defence and not for offence. For while the intention in such cases where the fair sex is concerned is to be equipped to defend herself against any attack against her modesty, it does not, of course, preclude her from giving way to temptation and using it for other non-defensive purposes.

    Secondly, Sir, there is no doubt in my mind that our regional effort in defence is inseparably bound up with our neighbour

Column: 322

Malaysia and tied to co-operation and assistance from our Commonwealth partners, the United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand. But we need to establish credibility and a sort of creditworthiness ourselves, so that our part of the bargain in the total set-up is not wholly insignificant or negative.

    Thirdly, Sir, I do not think, as the Member for Crawford might be anxious about, that the Vietnamese people after more than two decades of suffering, harassment and war, would want anything more than to enjoy the blessings of peace and to rebuild their economy and get on with the business of a normal peaceful existence once the war there is officially and technically over.

    I should like also to stress the point that it is of the utmost importance that while we make progress internally in strengthening our economic and defence sinews, internationally we should also make the maximum progress within our limited resources to seek and maintain the friendship of other nations, both big and small and whatever their ideology and systems of government. If by our defence policy and defence arrangements we can ensure that other nations would not be predisposed to be aggressive towards us, then to that extent we will feel assured of a basis for friendly relations, upon which we can further seek to enlarge by continuing to pursue a forward-looking policy.

    Since we extend the hand of friendship to all nations alike, there is also the need for us to maintain friendship even with those nations that may not be as friendly, in the hope that over the years they too will appreciate our gesture of friendship and discard any hostility or dissatisfaction which they may hold against us. The hard reality of international life is that today's foes can be tomorrow's friends. After all, governments are made up of human beings whose policies are subject to change depending on what is in their own respective interests.

    Our foreign policy is, briefly, in a sense, a most forward "defence" policy

Column: 323

that can be conceived, since it endeavours to secure the maximum of friends and ensure their friendship with us at all times and under all circumstances, whatever their own attitudes and reactions to other nations, in a way, our policy of friendship towards all nations indirectly supplements our security.

    On our non-aligned policy as brought up by the Member for Crawford, Sir, I already spoke at length last Thursday on this topic and I would not like to burden the House by unnecessarily repeating it all over again. However. I would again stress that our non- aligned policy is anchored to safe and unexceptionable premises which are beyond dispute and contradiction.
